20/03/25, 16:37 - Purvika Dasa Trainee TA Zyoin: *Hi all, please help me with this query*: Is it legally mandatory to provide Earned Leave (EL) in India? Our company currently offers only Casual Leave (CL) and Medical Leave (ML). Also, since we do not provide EL, should we explicitly mention in employee agreements that leave encashment is not applicable, or is it sufficient to include this in ourÂ leaveÂ policy?
20/03/25, 16:43 - Anjali Sathya TA Manager CADeploy Engineering: Hi All, 

Small suggestion required from you:

One of the process owner has asked to revoke the offer at the late stage (a day before the candidates last working in his current company) asking to revoked the offer due to management meeting and change in the hiring. 

How to sensitively handle this? (This impacts the brands reputation and candidates situation) <This message was edited>
20/03/25, 16:49 - Rohit Vatsyayan TA Head SwiffyLabs: No EL is not mandatory , any form of leave is okay
Atleast from what I know Karnataka mandates to have sort of leave encashment or carry forward every year (although companies have liberty to structure it in their own way)
Hence companies use EL as only type of leave covered in encashment/carry forward
20/03/25, 16:51 - Purvika Dasa Trainee TA Zyoin: Currently, we have this structure:
Casual leave - can carry forward up to 6 days every year
Medical leave - can not carry forward
20/03/25, 16:51 - Rohit Vatsyayan TA Head SwiffyLabs: Then itâ€™s sorted and compliant
20/03/25, 16:51 - Purvika Dasa Trainee TA Zyoin: Thanks a lot!
20/03/25, 17:37 - Kumuda Rao Co-founder Stochast: If you have to be labour law compliant, EL is mandatory. As per the Karnataka Shops and Commercial Establishments Act, every employee is entitled to annual leave with wages at the rate of one day for every twenty days of work performed by an adult employee and one day for every fifteen days of work performed by a young person.
20/03/25, 17:38 - Kumuda Rao Co-founder Stochast: Employees can carry forward up to 45 days of unused Earned Leave, providing flexibility for future use. At the end of employment, any unused Earned Leave is encashable, ensuring employees donâ€™t lose the benefit of their accrued time off.
20/03/25, 17:40 - Kumuda Rao Co-founder Stochast: All this will be caught during labour law audits or if an employee complains to labour law dept. However the leave clauses needs to be mentioned in the  policies and agreements.
20/03/25, 17:45 - Kumuda Rao Co-founder Stochast: I knew thiz for sure as I had faced 3 labour audits from labour dept and during which we had consulted the labour law expert... <This message was edited>
20/03/25, 17:51 - Roopa Puranikmath Sr. Lead Kyndryl: EL is statutory requirement
20/03/25, 17:56 - Roopa Puranikmath Sr. Lead Kyndryl: Leave encashment are part of exit mostly, carry forward is YOY thing.  You can add this as part of HR round of discussion for new hire. Rest details can be part of your policy document.  You have to be legally compliant.
20/03/25, 17:58 - Purvika Dasa Trainee TA Zyoin: Okay, thanks for inputs everyone!

With this, I also recall one more thing. Some companies mention that they do not provide leave encashment as they do not have the policy or they provide unlimited leaves. Is it legal? I have seen this in 2 companies, one is a start up, and one is an MNC.
20/03/25, 17:59 - Fireside Shiffana MK: I can help! Quick call or voice note ?
20/03/25, 18:01 - Fireside Shiffana MK: If unlimited leaves given, labour office is usually fine with it. I have managed that with them for some good 3 years straight with 4-5 audits. 
Encashment is not stringent - you can get away with that too. 

What is critical is if yiu have a structured leave policy, then 18 days of earned leave + 12 days of sick leave for tenured employees is roughly expected in karnataka.
20/03/25, 18:02 - Fireside Shiffana MK: What is more critical is identifying what will keep your team motivated and balancing that with law. Being compliant alone is not helpful in terms of building a culture imo
20/03/25, 18:02 - Purvika Dasa Trainee TA Zyoin: Giving you a call!
20/03/25, 18:10 - Anjali Sathya TA Manager CADeploy Engineering: Yes, please
20/03/25, 18:11 - Kumuda Rao Co-founder Stochast: We did the same but we were advised that of we have to be complaint then just be it or you may be lucky enough to get away with it. 

Leaving aside all these Statuory things, think from the point of what is the risk for business, what is beneficial to people..take a call on it.

Govt only manadates businesses to give the basic to employees. If the company is giving more, it doesn't ask.

02/04/25, 11:40 - Kunal Banerjee TA Specialist Freshworks: Hello peeps, here's a trivial question (which came to my mind while I was talking to a just-passed out-from-college and highly arrogant founder) 

"Till how many hires the founder should be involved in the hiring process?"

Asking since the founder (mentioned above) says that they would like to be involved till the team becomes 500 (currently it's at 10). To this I honestly thought that it's too much for a founder to focus on hiring till 500 and not focusing on scaling the ops, customer base (I may be wrong in my thinking) 

Putting forward this question to the group. Thoughts?
02/04/25, 11:42 - Mitali Jain CEO Scalent Solutions: I have seen early stage founders getting involved till 100. Up to 50 is usually high involvement.
02/04/25, 11:42 - Muneera Ghosh TA Manager Captain Fresh: I feel the founder should be involved in the initial set of hirings and also for  leadership hiring, apart from that I feel founders should be more focussed in scaling the app and operations
02/04/25, 11:42 - Kunal Banerjee TA Specialist Freshworks: Exactly, 500 is too over done! Arrogance at it's peak
02/04/25, 11:57 - Rohit Vatsyayan TA Head SwiffyLabs: After 50 they will stat becoming the bottleneck
Itâ€™s seems there is lack of maturity and fundamentals 
Running a tight ship= no final say other than founders is becoming a trend <This message was edited>
02/04/25, 11:58 - Mitali Jain CEO Scalent Solutions: He'll get a reality check in a few months
02/04/25, 12:00 - Gaurav Uniyal TA Head 91Squarefeet: Not more than 100, I think. Can be involved in senior leadership hiring or expansion hiring.
02/04/25, 12:05 - Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared: Depends on how fast the intended expansion to 500 people is. If over 2-3 years and above, sure. If within 6 months-1 year, then no. It really depends on what the person is looking for in these set of people. 500 is not a lot if growth is measured and organic.
02/04/25, 12:06 - Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared: Level of involvement is the real problem. because if they're micromanaging beyond the first 20 people, then it's already a bottleneck. so scale is not the real problem
02/04/25, 16:10 - Anupama Murthy Founder AVS Technology & Talent Consulting: Generally they get involved till they are 50 or so and after that he will not have anytime to interview. He may not be arrogant but itâ€™s all the initial enthusiasm thatâ€™s making him say that. You can tell him that itâ€™s great that he wants to get involved and leave it at that. Anyway when they grown eventually he can take a call. How does it matter now? <This message was edited>
02/04/25, 16:18 - Divya Chethan Founder CBREX: As a founder myself, I think it would probably be around 50. Its not scaleable otherwise. Maybe a max of upto 100. Then its your direct reportees who hv to manage and imbibe the same culture within the team
02/04/25, 16:20 - Divya Chethan Founder CBREX: But its extremely important to warm up the core team and the 1st 6-9 months  from their induction is crucial
02/04/25, 16:27 - Nidhi Kumar HR Head Imagekit.io: I think, its not about the number of people but the role you are hiring for. I worked with founders who loves to interview leadership or some sort of senior folks also after we acheived 450 employee strenght.
02/04/25, 16:29 - Kunal Banerjee TA Specialist Freshworks: Leadership is still fine, there the involvement is still required. This even large enterprise will also follow. Not for every role.
02/04/25, 17:31 - Ritika Sharma Sr. TA Partner Hackerrank: Founders' involvement in hiring decisions may stem from a lack of trust in their leadership team rather than arrogance. but to scale effectively, founders should empower their leaders to make hiring decisions for their respective orgs. It's understandable for founders to want to be involved in certain critical roles, such as product or leadership positions but beyond that is not scalable.

A possible solution is for founders to review candidates' overall scorecards or get involved at the offer approval stage. This allows them to stay informed about the strengths each new hire brings to the team without being overly involved in every hiring decision. our founder operates in this manner and it is working fine.
03/04/25, 09:47 - Neha Sahi Trell HR: Catching up on this thread a little late, but couldnâ€™t resist jumping in!

Echoing what a few folks have already shared â€” in the early days, the founderâ€™s involvement in hiring is super valuable. It helps shape culture, attract early believers, and build momentum. But staying involved in every hire till 500? That feels like overkill and honestly a recipe for burnout.

A more scalable approach is:
- Founder drives hiring till ~30â€“50,
- Stays involved in leadership roles till ~100â€“150,
- Then shifts focus to building a strong hiring engine with the right people and systems.

Founders should aim to hire people they trust to carry the culture forward, not stay stuck in the loop themselves. Otherwise, they risk being the bottleneck rather than the multiplier.

Really loved reading everyoneâ€™s perspectives on this!
03/04/25, 11:50 - Kunal Banerjee TA Specialist Freshworks: Thank you all for the perspective, basically i was correct in my thought process. 500 is a big number, sooner or later actual realisation will happen in the mind of the founder. That can show the founder to be a macro manager, which it actually sounded when I was talking to him. Max 50 is perfectly well, and then move the focus towards leadership hiring later on. 

Thank you all!

14/04/25, 15:00 - Neha Lakhwani Capillary: I think you can check but in my understanding itâ€™s not legally permissible to lay off during pregnancy

14/04/25, 15:13 - Krishna Vyas Carnot Lead HR: 3 major reasons -
Gross misconduct 
Contract expiry ( till her contract is valid you need to give, beyond that not required by law)
Non compliance with company rules ( this is where pip and other causes sit but very slippery slope )

16/04/25, 12:07 - Nataraja Nanjundaiah Credit Audit Payroll Expert: Q.3 What kind of scholarship is eligible for exemption under Section 10(16)?

All kinds of scholarships, including those granted by the government, educational institutions, or any other organization, are eligible for exemption under Section 10(16).
16/04/25, 12:08 - Nataraja Nanjundaiah Credit Audit Payroll Expert: it says above though it depends on how much is the quantum, what is the mechanism, judiciousness of how this is spent, these are the things you will need to show it to Income tax authorities if the scrutiny arises. Can you prove it appropriately or only a way to save tax for employees has to be clear. DM me and we can connect so I can help you on this
16/04/25, 12:10 - Kumuda Rao Co-founder Stochast: Yup. Good point. Scholarship income is not taxed basically but is not applicable to companies. Probably for education university employees it may be

22/04/25, 20:14 - Pallavi T Sr. TA Specialist Leap: At Headout, here's how it is: 

For SSE/SDE-2, the range is broad 30-50L cash (so for 3 yrs exp, would be 30-35L, 4 yrs would be 35-40L, 5 yrs would be 40-45L, 6 yrs would be 45-50L) + ESOPs (which is capped at 0.25x of their cash component)
For Lead/SDE-3, it's in the range of 50-65L + ESOPs. 

* with exceptions in some cases

Joining bonus is given in some cases.

24/04/25, 08:17 - Guntaas Lotay Sr. Recruiter Headout: Hey folks, did some research and thought of sharing here for everyoneâ€™s benefit:

1. Looked at two types of organisations to benchmark our bands with - ones that have commission based roles (DoorDash, eBay) versus others that have subscription based AE roles (Salesforce, Zendesk). Selling in the first bucket is relatively easier because you only make money if the partner business does (in this case, restaurants listed on DoorDash).
2. â The general split between base and OTE in commission based roles is 75:25 whereas in subscription selling is closer to 50:50.
3. â For the subscription based AE roles, the quotas for AEs are generally about 5x of their compensation. For eg: an AE who draws 100K USD will roughly have a target to sell contracts worth 500K in a year.
24/04/25, 08:53 - Sampath Arni Ravi HR TBC1:

24/04/25, 10:39 - Shivani Goyal TA Associate: Hey everyone
Are there any more suggestions on this one??
24/04/25, 10:43 - Mitali Jain CEO Scalent Solutions: What I have seen is Founder -> Subject Matter Expert -> Investor (if the role is critical and there are not many senior folks in the team). Real time case study solution + presentation could be an additional step.
24/04/25, 10:57 - Shivaraju K P TA Manager OppDoor: I have added my thoughts and structured them with the help of Chatgpt.

*1. Founder-Led Search (Warm Intros)*
Often, senior hires come through the founderâ€™s personal network or investor introductions.

This route is fast, trust-based, and ensures cultural alignmentâ€”especially when there's no structured leadership team in place yet.
Investors or advisors can play a strong role in vetting these candidates.

*2. Define the Role and First-Year Outcomes*
*Create a clear JD and 30-60-90 day plan focused on business outcomes, not just responsibilities.
*Define Year 1 OKRs aligned with company goalsâ€”this helps both in interviews and in setting expectations.
*Think in terms of "what problem are we hiring this person to solve?"

*3. Structured Founder + Panel Interviews*
Founders should do at least 2 rounds:

1st round: Vision alignment, business understanding.
2nd round: Execution mindset, team building, decision-making.
3rd round (optional): Deep dive into domain knowledge and prior experience.

*4. Bring in External Experts (VCs, Advisors, CXOs)*
If your company doesnâ€™t yet have senior folks internally, bring in domain or function-specific leaders from:
Your VCâ€™s portfolio companies
Trusted industry connections
Paid expert panels (if neededâ€”â‚¹5Kâ€“â‚¹15K per session is reasonable for CXOs' time)
These experts provide functional depth checks, red flags, and help avoid "founder blind spots."

*5. Case Study or Assignment (Optional but Powerful)*
Share a real business problem and see how the candidate would approach it. This gives deep insight into:
Strategic thinking
Stakeholder management
Business judgement

*6. Discreet Reference Checks*
Do 3â€“4 backchannel reference checks, beyond the names the candidate provides.
Focus on execution style, team management, and why they left past roles.
If any red flags arise, discuss them transparently with the candidate.
24/04/25, 11:05 - Shivani Goyal TA Associate: That's helpful, thanks Shiv! <This message was edited>

24/04/25, 11:23 - Kumuda Rao Co-founder Stochast: Detailed one. Challenge that I have seen in the past while hiring these senior roles first time is that the Org will not have much clarity, many a times we want this person to figure out in depth and solve. Also 6 rounds is a lot , isn't it?

Competencies required for this role and how and who is measuring it the interview rounds is important while objectively looking at hire or no hire in the end. 

Bringing in the external expert as suggested is good. 

Any hiring will be easy if we know what are the "must skills" and what are the "good to have skills"
24/04/25, 11:26 - Basant Mishra HR Partner MoEngage: <Media omitted>
24/04/25, 11:30 - Shivani Pande Sr. Manager People Success Rocketium: In early stages when we had to hire for such roles, it definitely started from the Founder chat first. In our case there were 1-2 more senior leaders so they would be involved too. 

Something we also actively did was to have other team members be the part of the process not necessarily for them to vote but to know about their experience of interacting with this senior person. Eventually this person will have to work with other members closely so it made sense to know what they thought about their interaction style. 

We sought support of our investors in doing one round of conversation at the end.

If there is a leaking bucket scenario, no specific number of TA folks would be able to support ğŸ˜Š. Your TA head will need all of this information to arrive at tge ideal team structure too. <This message was edited>

05/05/25, 19:02 - Ajith KP Director Talent Stellaris: Just had a similar conversation with one of our portfolio founders on this. Requirement of 100+ folks in field sales and collections, but on company payroll.  Asked him to go with staffing model, ready talent availability, less overheads, onus of replacement lies with staffing firm. Easy to monitor performance, have a quarterly review, get high performers on company payroll and nurture. Candidates are also comfortable with staffing firms as they are assured of a job if the opportunity doesn't work out, this is not possible on a company payroll. Not every candidate can perform in different sales setup.
05/05/25, 19:06 - Jayant Joshi Lead TA Opentext: Yes, true take a data driven decision for such a large scale / impact hiring

20/05/25, 12:42 - Shivani Goyal TA Associate: Hey All
I have a question.

We are a Fintech startup (soon to be Series A) based out of Bangalore.
We are struggling to hire Tech (Backend) & Product (PM & Designers) at our organization. One of the major filters for us for these roles is pedigree, as we hire from tier-1 engineering colleges only.
Also, our team is quite small to conduct a large number of interviews to get a higher number of selections.

Any suggestions on what we can do about this? Please feel free to DM in case you have any suggestions or need further information to share some insights.

20/05/25, 12:51 - Shivani Pande Sr. Manager People Success Rocketium: *My 2 cents:*
Go beyond the pedigree. If youâ€™re open to hiring early career folks (1-2 yrs), look for people at startups similar to your stage or maybe one step ahead. These folks have experienced the ambiguous environment and understand how things work at an early stage. They would also have solved problems from scratch.
Collect a few basic technical questions from your team and ask candidates these questions at your level of the call. These could also be questions with binary responses. I also often asked my team to give me questions and also hints for how to know if the candidate is giving the answer in the right direction (bâ€™cuz ofcourse these are technical questions, I would look for certain keywords they would use or approach they follow). This definitely reduced the rejections at the next stage.
Keep one round of technical interviews just for screening. Donâ€™t invest a lot of time here but only max 45 mins where one of your engineers does this round. If the candidate doesnâ€™t seem to be able to move the needle in the first 20-30 min, we would respectfully ask to close the call.

They have pricing for number of resumes like 5k/10k etc..and 3 plans if not mistaken

Zoho could be one more.. Not used much so can't comment..

All these are basics keeping in mind the cost

11/06/25, 12:05 - Pallavi T Sr. TA Specialist Leap: Agree with what Sukant said. If you plan to share the licenses do it smartly. I haven't seen the license being revoked so far.

12/06/25, 12:42 - Kumuda Rao Co-founder Stochast: If you are going to tier 1, understanding which day slot we are getting gives great clarity on campus talent availability. Few other things could be like: 
- offer to joining ratios
- whzt are the campus conditions If we have to revoke offer ( worst possible)
- how many multiple offers a student can have?
- Placement coordination team in these campuses are of great help.
- How will you derisk with similar talent off campus incase of offer drops.

19/06/25, 08:56 - Sampath Arni Ravi HR TBC1: To ensure authenticity, we request candidates to switch off their mobile phones during the interview and keep them away from the vicinity. We also conduct a discreet verification process where other team members may call the candidate to check if their phone is still off. This approach has helped us identify potential proxy candidates, and while some candidates have dropped out when informed of this process, it has proven effective in verifying candidate integrity.

And once they reach how many days of stay is being covered by the organisation ? Also the claw back is for typically how many months ? Any inputs would be really helpful
28/06/25, 13:52 - Kailuni Lanah HR TBC1: As a Series E funded unicorn, we offer comprehensive relocation support to new employees, which includes:
1. Economy class flight tickets for the employee and immediate family, 
2. Hotel accommodation for up to 15 days, 
3. â Reimbursement for the relocation of household goods, including two-wheelers or four-wheelers. 
4. Cover brokerage charges incurred for securing rental accommodation. 
5. Relocation expenses for household goods, including 2-4 wheelers, are subject to a 12-month clawback period.

01/07/25, 14:06 - Asmi Mittal Sr. Executive HR Ops Agrim: Hi, can anyone confirm how the intern to fulltime conversion usually happens at your organization?

Do you also practice the intern exit and then rejoining them as full time?
01/07/25, 14:13 - Gargi Rajan Associate Director HR Unicommerce: Yes they have to exit and next day oboarded as full time employee. There is no gap in between.
01/07/25, 14:14 - Gargi Rajan Associate Director HR Unicommerce: You have to roll out a offer letter to them for full time employment
01/07/25, 14:14 - Muskan Pasrija TA Specialist OfBusiness: Yes, in our organization, if an intern completes their internship on 30th June, we treat that as their Last Working Day as an intern. If they are being converted to full-time, we carry out the onboarding formalities again from 1st July.

This approach is followed primarily in cases where the intern was initially hired only for the internship, and no pre-placement offer was extended at the beginning.

*For example*, when we hire interns specifically from campus, we issue a letter stating that they will work as interns for six months, after which their designation and package will be revised to a full-time role. In such cases, there is no exit or re-onboarding process involved - they continue seamlessly into the full-time position.
01/07/25, 14:21 - Asmi Mittal Sr. Executive HR Ops Agrim: Thank you for the clarity
01/07/25, 15:01 - Komal Patil HR Ops Specialist Companystore.io: yes!! if intern completes his/her tenure as an intern we exit them as an intern and onboard them again freshly as a new employee.

and later, after internal discussion, the CTC and designation were officially changed within the first week of joining â€”

ğŸ‘‰ Can we issue an updated offer letter reflecting the revised CTC and designation, or is it not allowed once the initial offer has been issued?

18/07/25, 19:31 - Shiv Jha Associate Director TA Zolo: Hi all, Iâ€™d appreciate your thoughts on this situation.

I have an employee in the night shift who has recently been taking frequent leaves citing medical issues. When she does report to work, she often signs off early and delegates her responsibilities to others, sometimes without my knowledge. This pattern has continued for the past two months.

While Iâ€™ve been accommodating so far, itâ€™s starting to affect team productivity and morale. Whatâ€™s more concerning is that 2-3 other employees have started following the same pattern after observing her behavior.

Iâ€™m considering offering her a 10-day medical leave to focus on her health and return with clarity. Alternatively, would it be fair to ask her to resign with a two-month notice period - one month being mandatory and the second flexible if she finds another opportunity?

I understand that asking someone to leave due to health concerns is sensitive and ethically tricky, but the indirect work-shifting and growing ripple effect on the team are now hampering operations.

Would love your input on how best to address this.
18/07/25, 19:33 - Lijo Varghese TA Manager HealthifyMe: Your idea of a 10-day paid medical leave is a great middle ground. It shows care and gives her space to recover, but also sets a timeline for clarity. Make it clear that sheâ€™s expected to return either fit to work or with further recommendations.
18/07/25, 19:34 - Lijo Varghese TA Manager HealthifyMe: If she returns but the pattern continues, document all instances and have a formal performance discussion. Let her know that unless thereâ€™s improvement, you may need to explore alternate arrangements, including a structured transition or even separation (in line with policy
18/07/25, 19:35 - Shiv Jha Associate Director TA Zolo: Thanks Lijo!
18/07/25, 19:37 - Roopa Puranikmath Sr. Lead Kyndryl: First you should have one on One with her, show empathy and understand things from her point of view.  Only thing that you should do right now is to keep things in writing.  See the outcome.  If she has personal issues with health then grant her 10 days leave as per policy coverage if you have one in place.  if she expresses difficulty in working in night shift check employment guidelines in offer letter mostly it will all be covered.  Then bring this matter to your management and keep HR informed.
18/07/25, 19:41 - Shiv Jha Associate Director TA Zolo: So far I have had informal chats, she generally has health concerns on Friday. 29/07/25, 11:32 - GV Sridharan Director TA & Ops Astuto: Regarding their pricing. Few tips that I follow and have found success most of the time. 
1. Make sure your renewal is in the month of March every year, so they will negotiate more
2. I do not renew immediately. I let go for a month after the renewal date and then the CS team calls to negotiate. When they come back we have better chances on negotiating

07/08/25, 15:00 - Shivani Goyal TA Associate: Hi All

07/08/25, 15:17 - Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared: Lot of them are actually very active on X. Identify a design leader there with good reach and ask them to share a post - they'll do so only if your product has good design philosophy/foundation behind it or product is compelling itself (and design is lacking). You'll get the ones hiding in pockets be interested in your role - you have to love bomb them here because if you don't take care of them here (whether a fit or not), the others will just never come to you again (good designers have a small community and word travels very fast)

traditional method is to explore portfolios around an idea via dribble, indiefolio, etc. these are usually curated by the platform, and then message them on LI.

old method is to post job for them in such platforms, which works but good designers don't have time to see roles on those sites - they see them on LI
07/08/25, 15:21 - Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared: We discussed the process earlier here :)

26/08/25, 16:45 - Sai Akhil People's Team Manager Ivy Homes: Hey All,

We are looking to launch a internal referral program for our company. Majority of the role that are open on a recurring basis are non tech roles such as Sales and BD.

I'd appreciate any suggestions on what I need to have in a referral policy and what should the benifits we need to provide to someone who reffers a candidate and they get selectedm
26/08/25, 17:33 - Roopa Puranikmath Sr. Lead Kyndryl: Few I can think of 1) Payout timeline 2) Reference bonus applies to post joining only Not offer roll out/selection 3) You should have some math on what the referral amount is. Gen. fresher referrals do not work for payouts. Position Band, Salary range can be equated to arrive at what can be referral bonus. 3) Who is eligible to refer. (Exclude who are under investigation, exit pipeline) 5) You may want to think of unlimited referrals / cap on x no of referrals per employee.  6) For calculation only basic salary range will apply 7) Are referrals bonus payout taxable (get view from payroll team) in reality its yes 8) When will referral bonus payout gets credited; immediately post joining or in the salary cycle. But you should have solution sorted for a possible situation of, if joiner quits before bonus payout!  Trust this helps, let me know.

New CXO is hiring few folks (more junior to the aforementioned leaders) but his judgement is dissimilar from the group. These leaders took interviews of these folks but donâ€™t find them good enough for the team at the proposed level. These leaders donâ€™t want to ruin their relationship with the CXO either (CXO is not their manager). how do you advise your leader stakeholder in sharing this feedback candidly without offending yet making the right decision together (nothing can be written)
01/09/25, 21:49 - Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared: Detail: The interviewed folks were referred by the CXO ^
01/09/25, 21:54 - Shivani Pande Sr. Manager People Success Rocketium: - Are these junior folks for the same CXO's team or other? 
- What I've seen work in my case is candidly sharing examples of how people with certain traits similar to these referred folks, multiple times did not work well for the team's performance density and culture in the past.

If the leader is mature enough, they'll understand if this is shared with the right intent and demeanor.
01/09/25, 21:57 - Mitali Jain CEO Scalent Solutions: I think there cannot be a blanket answer to this. The stakeholders and CXO should have a one-on-one for each candidate or all candidates together and the stakeholder/s should put across why they think these folkâ€™s wonâ€™t be a good fit. The CXO might have solid reasoning for referring some of these candidates. Basically, a rational and candid conversation between two hightly experienced folks
02/09/25, 03:06 - Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared: Thank you for these points. Main challenge is, while your intent is right - the CXO would feel not supported at the outset. Top is especially political as is and it frays relationships really badly, often beyond repair and actual trust. My stakeholders are struggling exactly with this.
02/09/25, 03:07 - Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared: Itâ€™s a hard pill to communicate either way, just have to be respectful. 09/09/25, 12:41 - Arun Kumar D Sr. Lead TA Contentstack: First things first, start building a fresh pipeline. On the offered candidate, I had faced a similar situation a few weeks back. I tried engaging with the candidate in detail to understand his true intent â€” pushed for in-person meetups, resignation email, residential address for couriering gifts, and BGV checks. Eventually, he gave up and officially declined the offer, luckily a month before his joining date. In this case, we canâ€™t push the candidate until they officially decline after securing another offer, so it may take some time.

19/09/25, 08:51 - You pinned a message
19/09/25, 12:32 - Shivaraju K P TA Manager OppDoor: Quick question â€” whatâ€™s the law around unlimited leave policies? Do companies with such policies allow encashment of leaves? If not isn't it non compliant ?
19/09/25, 12:36 - Shivani Pande Sr. Manager People Success Rocketium: - Encashment is not mandatory. 
- Law doesn't speak for unlimited leaves. Its only a matter of audits that some day if there is an audit and the labour department observes that your folks have not been allowed to take off days atleast the minimum that's said by the law, then there will be a problem. Startups usually don't face such strong checks.

As far as the company is not restricting employees from taking the minimum applicable time off, all is ok. <This message was edited>
19/09/25, 12:45 - Shivaraju K P TA Manager OppDoor: Not as per our compliance advisor, earned leaves have to be encashed.

Earned Leave (EL) / Privilege Leave (PL)
Employees in Karnataka are entitled to 15 days of Earned Leave per year, with an annual leave carry forward limit recently increased from 30 days to 45 days under the Shops & Commercial Establishments Act. This leave accrues at the rate of one day for every 20 days worked, allowing for a steady accumulation throughout the year. Employees can carry forward up to 45 days of unused Earned Leave, providing flexibility for future use. At the end of employment, any unused Earned Leave is encashable, ensuring employees donâ€™t lose the benefit of their accrued time off.
19/09/25, 12:46 - Shivani Pande Sr. Manager People Success Rocketium: Not if you don't have earned leaves ğŸ˜…
19/09/25, 12:50 - Shivani Pande Sr. Manager People Success Rocketium: This is more of relevance in cases where there is a formal leave policy, because then you also deduct pay when anyone has consumed the leaves. 
In an unlimited format, you're deducting the pay is not a part of any situation, so the company can get away with not giving earned leaves.
19/09/25, 12:53 - Shivaraju K P TA Manager OppDoor: Our advisor advised that we have to provide the earned/privileged leaves, as these are mandatoryğŸ˜€. We had to revise our leaves to 18 EL per year.
But it is not fun tracking attendance when people just don't apply leaves on the toolğŸ˜”
19/09/25, 12:56 - Shivaraju K P TA Manager OppDoor: If a company has an unlimited leave policy and no earned leave (EL), they will still have to pay up to 45 days of leave encashment if an employee raises a legal issue.
19/09/25, 12:56 - Shivani Pande Sr. Manager People Success Rocketium: Yeah, that's true :)
19/09/25, 12:58 - Shivani Pande Sr. Manager People Success Rocketium: But, if these are tracked and the employee has taken leaves more than the entitled ELs, then the company can also show that they've consumed these many.
19/09/25, 13:01 - Shivaraju K P TA Manager OppDoor: Yep, there are multiple registers we will have to maintain as well to track them.

We have been asked to maintain 
Shops and Establishments Act Form F- Register of Leave with Wage
Shops and Establishments Act Form H- Leave with wage book

20/09/25, 10:36 - Ashwini Kumar Madireddy HR TBC1: We follow : 
Casual Leave - 6 days / year
Sick Leave - 6 days / year 
Earned Leave - 13 days / year for first three years , 15 days/ year for 4th and 5th year , 18 days from 6th year of service . 
All leaves are credited on quarterly basis . Max accumulation - 45 days .
Leave encashment only on separation .

National and Festival Holidays - 10 per year 
Restricted Holidays 2 per year

09/10/25, 21:49 - Guntaas Lotay Sr. Recruiter Headout: Hi! Weâ€™ve not hired AEs in India but Iâ€™ll give you a breakdown of what we follow for RoW:

1. For the sales process, broad strokes of whatâ€™s evaluated in these rounds:
- Past performance: what kind of quota/KPIs did they carry? How familiar are they with their funnel conversions? Comfort with CRM and other dashboarding tools. Examples of difficult deals theyâ€™ve worked on are discussed and our team has a bit of sales role play to identify how they do discovery, overcome objections, etc.
2. â In terms of sourcing channels, LinkedIn has worked best (both inbound through job postings and outreach that we do). Response rates for outreach typically range between 30-45% depending on geography. Weâ€™ve also tried out some country specific job boards too.
3. â Generally 3 discussion rounds (recruiter < case study < reporting manager < leadership)

In terms of learnings, weâ€™ve seen that at least in the context of Headout, folks who have tackled problem statements outside of just pure sales tend to be better fits. <This message was edited>

11/10/25, 15:44 - Sunit Desai Sr. Manager People Experience CashFlo: Hey Guys needed your suggestions. Just wanted to know how many days to you guys give to a consultant to give a replacement, if their provided candidate leaves within 3 months.
Thanks in advance 
Sunit
11/10/25, 16:15 - Suyash Kumar: Folks, any insights here?
11/10/25, 16:19 - Ajith KP Director Talent Stellaris: It depends on the reason behind the candidate leaving the organisation. If it is due to org restrucutre and mishire, then it's on the firm to own up. If it is due to candidate changing their mind and joining another firm, then a replacement is mandated. If the invoice is not processed, then this can be held against the consultant till a replacement is found.
Typically, replacement should be provided by the consultant within a reasonable period of 30-60 days.
11/10/25, 16:25 - Sunit Desai Sr. Manager People Experience CashFlo: Thanks Ajith

11/10/25, 21:17 - Clive Rodrigues HR Livspace: @â¨Sunit Desai Sr. Manager People Experience CashFloâ© - I'm guessing your vendor contract would already be signed & this would already be enforceable. Happy to share specific insights or guidance, if required
11/10/25, 22:45 - Sivakanth Pappu TA Specialist Lifesight: Iâ€™m actively hiring for these exact roles at a B2B SaaS startup myself.
11/10/25, 23:09 - Sivakanth Pappu TA Specialist Lifesight: Ideal Background:
	â€¢	Tier 1 or Tier 2 college background or strong startup experience (B2B or B2C)
	â€¢	Demonstrated career growth. e.g., promotions, awards, or performance recognition

Evaluation Criteria (Current & Past Experience)
	1.	Targets: What revenue or quota targets do they carry?
	2.	Ownership: Are these individual (IC) or team targets?
	3.	Attainment - What percentage of target achievement have they demonstrated?
	â€¢	Cross-verify with deal size to ensure consistency (many AEs get filtered out here as the numbers often donâ€™t align).
	4.	Can they design or tailor solutions to client needs? (Key criterion for us)
	5.	Do they independently close deals?
       6.  Double down on evaluating any short stints in their past experience

Candidate Sourcing Channels
	â€¢	100% Outbound: LinkedIn & LinkedIn Recruiter Lite

Interview Process
	1.	TA Intro Call (15â€“20 mins) â€“ Initial screening and interest check
	2.	Round 1: Co-founder discussion
	3.	Round 2: Take-home assignment â€“ Candidate to research the product and prepare a product pitch
	â€¢	This is where most AEs are filtered out, as it tests their product understanding, articulation, and solutioning capability.
	4.	Round 3 (Final): CEO interview

- Many valuable and unique learnings, too detailed to cover here

29/10/25, 17:26 - Suyash Kumar: 1. Be professional
2. Treat others online as you would treat them in real life
3. Be tolerant towards othersâ€™ viewpoints; respectfully disagree when opinions do not align
4. Respect the privacy and personal information of other community members
5. Communicate with courtesy and respect
29/10/25, 17:26 - Suyash Kumar: 6. Avoid using the group for DMs - If thereâ€™s a topic that only concerns you and one other person, please DM them about it.
7. Strictly NO BUSINESS or EVENT PROMOTIONS allowed in the community without the ADMIN'S EXPRESS APPROVAL
8. Strictly NO SPAM

03/11/25, 10:48 - Gargi Rajan Associate Director HR Unicommerce: Apart from the regular interviews - TA screening , founders, stakeholders,  i would suggest to get one round done by a  HR head (from Startups) from anyone in the network of the founders

04/11/25, 12:32 - Dhriti Mahajan Talent kipi.bi: Hey, for hiring our first HRBP, I suggest a 3-step interview process.
Round 1:  C Suite round - CEO or functional leadership- discussion to assess business alignment, ownership mindset, and how they think about scaling people strategy in a fast-growing setup - strategic PMS, culture evangelism, roadmap to expand and support BUs.
Round 2: Functional or case-based round to test execution skills/ assessment followed by a C Suite interaction to discuss the assessment detailsâ€”e.g., how theyâ€™d build HR systems, performance frameworks, and culture as we scale from 50â€“200 employees. KRA mapping, OD interventions.
Round 3: Culture and stakeholder-fit discussion to gauge communication, influence, and ability to partner with business teams, BU Heads, engaging strategic ESAT etc.
Optionally, we can involve an external HR advisor for one round to validate depth on compliance, PMS, and process design. This structure gives us a fair balance of strategy, execution, and culture evaluation
04/11/25, 12:33 - Shivani Goyal TA Associate: Thanks!
This is helpful

14/11/25, 22:22 - Shraddha Agrawal HR Manager ClearFeed: - consider medical GMC (minimum ) and accidental (based on budget) to start with. 
- â Employe, spouse and kids (minimum) 
- â Parents insurance will require higher head count, if you at below 50 employees many insurers will not consider 
- â between 5L - 10L Sum Insured is good to start with 

Also look at the demographics of your employees in what age group they are, if people are say 30-35 years above they would ideally expect parents, spouse, kids insurance and good sum insured. 

The more head count you have better per life premium you can negotiate.
